intro: Hieracium filiferum, commonly known as the hairy hawkweed, is a perennial flowering plant belonging to the Asteraceae family. It is characterized by its basal rosette of hairy, lance-shaped leaves and produces yellow composite flowers in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in moist meadows, woodland edges, and disturbed sites across Europe and parts of Asia. It has a taproot system and can form dense colonies, sometimes becoming invasive in certain regions. Its flowers are arranged in a single, flat-topped inflorescence, and it is known for its ability to thrive in a variety of soil conditions.
